The education for Americans on the atomic bombings is very spotty, and one of the things that I've found in my work is that a lot of World War II memory resides through the family, and a lot of World War II memory is different, depending on which coast you grew up in.
On the West Coast, people are much more likely to be attuned to things like Japanese--the internment camps for Japanese-Americans and much more likely to be attuned to the atomic bombings.

On the East Coast, while those things are certainly known and the internment camps increasingly known since the 1970s, there tends to be an emphasis on Holocaust education, and it's education into the Holocaust which tends to come first.
